content: Why is NutritionOrder inpatient only. I certainly see it applicable to Kidney dialysis/CKD patients and in other outpatient chronic care settings where complex care is delivered.

@Hans Buitendijk @Riki Merrick @David Burgess @Lorraine Constable @Rob Hausam @Ralf Herzog @John David Larkin Nolen Hi Folks, this is your resource. Can I get a little feedback on my question above? @Becky Gradl
Hi Gay, the initial work focused on inpatient orders. We are currently working on extending that, and are working on related use cases. @Becky Gradl - any sme level comments?

Hi Lorraine - Thanks for replying, what is the ETA on the new work? I am interested in hearing from @Becky Gradl - I'm not a nutritionist - but I am a nurse and I am not seeing any preclusion in using it for the use cases I mention above.

I think I see the problem/restriction:
NutritionOrder

Definition
A request to supply a diet, formula feeding (enteral) or oral nutritional supplement to a patient/resident.
So - an actual diet has to be supplied in the use case of this profile

I don't know the history on the creation of NutritionOrder, but @Margaret Dittloff may be able to shed some light on that. The issue of using NutritionOrder in an outpatient setting has been raised in the past, however since it was not an urgent issue, no work has been done to see if it would work. We would need to do a walk-through of the resource to see if in its current state it might work in an outpatient setting for a "nutrition prescription" (i.e. a suggested diet to follow) and determine if it needs any modifications or a new resource. In this instance, I would think the diet (that would typically be used for a diet order) could be used for the "nutrition prescription". There is a bi-weekly Nutrition call on Wednesdays under O&O where we discuss nutrition topics. This would be the best place to have this conversation.
I don't see any reason for outpatients to be explicitly excluded. I will join the call today and if this is in the agenda, I'd like to see if/why this is excluded.
